mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle\delta G(B)&\displaystyle=G(B)-G(0)\\
&\displaystyle\approx\alpha_{\phi}\frac{e^{2}}{2\pi\hbar}\left[ln\left(\frac{B%
_{\phi}}{B}\right)-\psi\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{B_{\phi}}{B}\right)\right]\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>≈</mo><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} has two extra correction terms compared to Eq-\ref{eq-redHLN}. The second term is similar to the first in form, but it represents the contribution from elastic scattering\cite{HLN80,Zhang_60T_12,Dey14}. The prefactor $\alpha_{eff}$ is an indicator of multiple channels effectively contributing to the correction. The final term is the conventional quadratic cyclotron term, which provides a negative correction to the overall conductivity\cite{Assaf_extHLN_13,Shekhar_BTS_14}. The extended HLN fit of Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} proves more reliable for full-range fitting (solid lines in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(b)). The characteristic lengths associated with the two dephasing fields in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN}, $L_\phi,\ L_\varepsilon$ and the reduced HLN $L_\phi$, are shown as a function of temperature in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(c) matching closely. The dashed line represents a $T^{-0.51}$ dependence, which is an attribute of a 2D system and corresponds to Nyquist electron-electron decoherence\cite{Altshuler_EEI_82,Lee_BSTS_12,Dey14}. The elastic scattering length $L_\varepsilon<L_\phi$ and changes relatively little over the temperature range. $\alpha_\phi$ v $T$ from both the fits are shown in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(d) matching relatively well. The equivalent prefactor of the surface channel in the extended HLN fit is obtained from the effective prefactor as $\alpha_\phi = \alpha_{eff}/2$. As before, $\alpha_\phi$ is slightly larger than $1/2\pi$ at lower temperatures for both fits, indicating the presence of mainly a symplectic 2D channel, partially decoupled with the bulk states, contributing to the WAL. It is also instructive to consider the value of $\pi\alpha_{eff}$, which is $\sim1.5$. A value larger than unity indicates the presence of more than one channel contributing\cite{Lee_BSTS_12}, especially with the elastic scattering term in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN}. The data at 60K is almost parabolic with a very small WAL feature, such that the first and second terms in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} act equivalently for the purposes of the fit and gives larger error in the reduced HLN case. The fitting parameter $\beta$ can be expressed as $\mu_{MR}^2 G_\square(0)$, where $\mu_{MR}$ is the mobility estimated from the parabolic MR term and for isotropic scattering $\mu_{MR}$ should be approximately similar to $\mu_{Hall}$\cite{SchroderBook}. The $\mu_{MR}$ from the fit is very close to the Hall mobility (Fig-\ref{fig-2chvT}(b)), i.e., $\sim 150$ cm$^2$/V$\cdot$s. The temperature-dependent 2D behavior of $L_\phi$ and the values of $\alpha_\phi$ can be understood as arising from topological surface channel contributing to the WAL cusp, while the conductive bulk also contributes to the high-field MR behavior. In prior study on Bi$_2$Te$_3$ films, additional conductivity correction terms in the HLN equation from spin-orbit scattering, were also considered\cite{Zhang_60T_12,Dey14}. However, for our data the spin-orbit dephasing fields $B_{SOx,z}\ggg B_\phi,B_\varepsilon$, hence could be safely ignored from the fit. The contribution from the WAL effect dominates the conductivity at low-temperatures and at zero-field. The expected quantum correction to the temperature-dependent conductivity in disordered systems due to localization is (in units of $e^2/h$):

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\delta G(B)\approx\frac{\alpha_{eff}}{2}\frac{e^{2}}{2\pi\hbar}%
\left[ln\left(\frac{B_{\phi}}{B}\right)-\psi\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{B_{\phi}}{%
B}\right)\right]\\
\displaystyle+\alpha_{eff}\frac{e^{2}}{2\pi\hbar}\left[ln\left(\frac{B_{%
\varepsilon}}{B}\right)-\psi\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{B_{\varepsilon}}{B}\right)%
\right]-\beta B^{2}" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>α</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ε</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>ε</mi></msub><mi>B</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: Where the phase coherence time $\tau_\phi\sim T^{-p}$ ($p=1$ for 2D), $\alpha_{qc}$ is a prefactor similar in nature to $\alpha_\phi$ from the HLN fit and $T_L$ is the temperature at which the correction disappears\cite{Beutler_EEI_88,Takagaki_CuBS_12,Lu_EEIWAL_14}. The conductivity should continue to increase with decreasing temperature for a purely WAL-like contribution. However, as discussed in Section \ref{sec-RvT}, the devices show a decrease in the conductivity with decreasing temperature, which is linearly proportional to logarithmic temperature and is attributed to EEI. The EEI correction is also logarithmic in nature similar to Eq-\ref{eq-qcond}, as seen from Eq-\ref{eq-EEI}. The low-temperature conductivity in different perpendicular magnetic fields can be then fitted to a generic equation of the form (in units of $e^2/h$):
prevtext: Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} has two extra correction terms compared to Eq-\ref{eq-redHLN}. The second term is similar to the first in form, but it represents the contribution from elastic scattering\cite{HLN80,Zhang_60T_12,Dey14}. The prefactor $\alpha_{eff}$ is an indicator of multiple channels effectively contributing to the correction. The final term is the conventional quadratic cyclotron term, which provides a negative correction to the overall conductivity\cite{Assaf_extHLN_13,Shekhar_BTS_14}. The extended HLN fit of Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} proves more reliable for full-range fitting (solid lines in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(b)). The characteristic lengths associated with the two dephasing fields in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN}, $L_\phi,\ L_\varepsilon$ and the reduced HLN $L_\phi$, are shown as a function of temperature in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(c) matching closely. The dashed line represents a $T^{-0.51}$ dependence, which is an attribute of a 2D system and corresponds to Nyquist electron-electron decoherence\cite{Altshuler_EEI_82,Lee_BSTS_12,Dey14}. The elastic scattering length $L_\varepsilon<L_\phi$ and changes relatively little over the temperature range. $\alpha_\phi$ v $T$ from both the fits are shown in Fig-\ref{fig-MRvT}(d) matching relatively well. The equivalent prefactor of the surface channel in the extended HLN fit is obtained from the effective prefactor as $\alpha_\phi = \alpha_{eff}/2$. As before, $\alpha_\phi$ is slightly larger than $1/2\pi$ at lower temperatures for both fits, indicating the presence of mainly a symplectic 2D channel, partially decoupled with the bulk states, contributing to the WAL. It is also instructive to consider the value of $\pi\alpha_{eff}$, which is $\sim1.5$. A value larger than unity indicates the presence of more than one channel contributing\cite{Lee_BSTS_12}, especially with the elastic scattering term in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN}. The data at 60K is almost parabolic with a very small WAL feature, such that the first and second terms in Eq-\ref{eq-extHLN} act equivalently for the purposes of the fit and gives larger error in the reduced HLN case. The fitting parameter $\beta$ can be expressed as $\mu_{MR}^2 G_\square(0)$, where $\mu_{MR}$ is the mobility estimated from the parabolic MR term and for isotropic scattering $\mu_{MR}$ should be approximately similar to $\mu_{Hall}$\cite{SchroderBook}. The $\mu_{MR}$ from the fit is very close to the Hall mobility (Fig-\ref{fig-2chvT}(b)), i.e., $\sim 150$ cm$^2$/V$\cdot$s. The temperature-dependent 2D behavior of $L_\phi$ and the values of $\alpha_\phi$ can be understood as arising from topological surface channel contributing to the WAL cusp, while the conductive bulk also contributes to the high-field MR behavior. In prior study on Bi$_2$Te$_3$ films, additional conductivity correction terms in the HLN equation from spin-orbit scattering, were also considered\cite{Zhang_60T_12,Dey14}. However, for our data the spin-orbit dephasing fields $B_{SOx,z}\ggg B_\phi,B_\varepsilon$, hence could be safely ignored from the fit. The contribution from the WAL effect dominates the conductivity at low-temperatures and at zero-field. The expected quantum correction to the temperature-dependent conductivity in disordered systems due to localization is (in units of $e^2/h$):

Where the phase coherence time $\tau_\phi\sim T^{-p}$ ($p=1$ for 2D), $\alpha_{qc}$ is a prefactor similar in nature to $\alpha_\phi$ from the HLN fit and $T_L$ is the temperature at which the correction disappears\cite{Beutler_EEI_88,Takagaki_CuBS_12,Lu_EEIWAL_14}. The conductivity should continue to increase with decreasing temperature for a purely WAL-like contribution. However, as discussed in Section \ref{sec-RvT}, the devices show a decrease in the conductivity with decreasing temperature, which is linearly proportional to logarithmic temperature and is attributed to EEI. The EEI correction is also logarithmic in nature similar to Eq-\ref{eq-qcond}, as seen from Eq-\ref{eq-EEI}. The low-temperature conductivity in different perpendicular magnetic fields can be then fitted to a generic equation of the form (in units of $e^2/h$):

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle\delta G_{\phi}^{2}\rangle=\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\pi^{2}h}\right)^{2}\sum_%
{n_{x}=1,n_{y}=-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{12g_{s}g_{v}}{\left(n_{x}^{2}+4\left(%
\frac{L}{W}\right)^{2}n_{y}^{2}\right)^{2}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mi>ϕ</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>y</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>v</mi></msub></mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mi>W</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>n</mi><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: Where $\sigma, \sigma_b$ and $G^{ss}_\square$ are the total conductivity, bulk conductivity and surface state (SS) conductance, respectively. Assuming that the bulk conductivity component is largely independent of the thickness of the film, and that the SS conductance follows the 2D EEI relation of Eq-\ref{appeq-EEI2ch} (up to some correction factor converting between conductance and conductivity), a temperature-dependent conductivity correction can be written as:

prevtext: Where $\sigma, \sigma_b$ and $G^{ss}_\square$ are the total conductivity, bulk conductivity and surface state (SS) conductance, respectively. Assuming that the bulk conductivity component is largely independent of the thickness of the film, and that the SS conductance follows the 2D EEI relation of Eq-\ref{appeq-EEI2ch} (up to some correction factor converting between conductance and conductivity), a temperature-dependent conductivity correction can be written as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle\frac{\partial\sigma}{\partial T}&\displaystyle%
\approx\frac{\partial\sigma_{b}}{\partial T}+\frac{C}{d\cdot T}\\
\displaystyle\mbox{At the resistance minima, }&\displaystyle T=T_{min},\ \frac%
{\partial\sigma}{\partial T}=0\\
\displaystyle\therefore 0&\displaystyle\approx\frac{\partial\sigma_{b}}{%
\partial T}\bigg{|}_{T_{min}}+\frac{C}{d\cdot T_{min}}\\
\displaystyle\therefore T_{min}&\displaystyle\approx\bigg{(}\frac{-C}{\frac{%
\partial\sigma_{b}}{\partial T}\big{|}_{T_{min}}}\bigg{)}\cdot\frac{1}{d}\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mtext>At the resistance minima, </mtext></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi/><mo>∴</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>≈</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo fence="true" maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">|</mo></mrow><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi/><mo>∴</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mrow><mo minsize="210%">(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><msub><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo fence="true" maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">|</mo></mrow><msub><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></msub></mfrac><mo maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>d</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: Where $n_i,\ \mu_i$ are the carrier concentration and mobility of the $i^{\mbox{th}}$ channel, respectively. $G_{XX,\ XY}$ are the conductance tensor components. With some basic algebra and limiting assumptions the number of unknown variables in the fit can be reduced and the following equation can be used for a two-channel model\cite{Bansal_TI_12}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="G_{XX}=e\sum_{i}\frac{n_{i}\mu_{i}}{1+\mu_{i}^{2}B^{2}},\ G_{XY}=eB\sum_{i}%
\frac{n_{i}\mu_{i}^{2}}{1+\mu_{i}^{2}B^{2}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: Where $n_i,\ \mu_i$ are the carrier concentration and mobility of the $i^{\mbox{th}}$ channel, respectively. $G_{XX,\ XY}$ are the conductance tensor components. With some basic algebra and limiting assumptions the number of unknown variables in the fit can be reduced and the following equation can be used for a two-channel model\cite{Bansal_TI_12}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle G_{XY}\\
\displaystyle=&\displaystyle eB\left(\frac{k_{1}\mu_{1}-k_{2}}{\left(\frac{\mu%
_{1}}{\mu_{2}}-1\right)\cdot(1+\mu_{2}^{2}B^{2})}+\frac{k_{1}\mu_{2}-k_{2}}{%
\left(\frac{\mu_{2}}{\mu_{1}}-1\right)\cdot(1+\mu_{1}^{2}B^{2})}\right)\\
\displaystyle k_{1}&\displaystyle=G_{XX}(0)/e,\ k_{2}=\lim_{B\to 0}G_{XY}(B)/%
eB\\
\displaystyle n_{1}&\displaystyle=\frac{k_{1}\mu_{2}-k_{2}}{\mu_{1}\mu_{2}-\mu%
_{1}^{2}},\ n_{2}=\frac{k_{1}\mu_{1}-k_{2}}{\mu_{1}\mu_{2}-\mu_{2}^{2}}\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>μ</mi><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo
